metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Apply the quantised energy of photons: E = hf = hc/λ

quantisation_definition.name: Quantisation Definition
quantisation_definition.correct: Quantised means energy can only exist in specific discrete amounts, not any value. Photon energy is fixed by its frequency.

continuous.error: That's the opposite. Continuous means any value is possible.
continuous.fix: Quantised = discrete = specific allowed values only. Like steps, not a ramp.
continuous.action: Think: can you have half a photon? No. Energy comes in whole packets.

random.error: Quantised doesn't mean random. Each photon has a definite energy.
random.fix: The energy is determined by frequency: E = hf. Not random at all.
random.action: Calculate E for f = 5 × 10¹⁴ Hz. You'll get one specific answer.

variable.error: Variable suggests it can change continuously. Quantised means fixed packets.
variable.fix: A photon's energy is fixed once its frequency is set.
variable.action: A 500 nm photon always has the same energy. Always.

persistent.gap: You're confusing quantised (discrete packets) with continuous (any value).
persistent.action: Visualise: stairs vs ramp. Energy levels are stairs, not a smooth ramp.

photon_definition.name: Photon Definition
photon_definition.correct: A photon is a massless particle of electromagnetic radiation with a discrete amount of energy determined by its frequency.

a wave of light.error: That's the wave model. Photons are the particle model.
a wave of light.fix: Photon = particle aspect of light. Each photon carries one quantum of energy.
a wave of light.action: Light has wave-particle duality. Photon refers to the particle aspect.

an electron emitted from light.error: That's a photoelectron, not a photon.
an electron emitted from light.fix: Photon = light particle. Photoelectron = electron ejected by light.
an electron emitted from light.action: Photo-n = light particle. Photo-electron = electron from light.

a charged particle.error: Photons have no charge. They're electrically neutral.
a charged particle.fix: Photons are massless AND chargeless. They carry energy, not charge.
a charged particle.action: Light doesn't bend in electric fields. Why? Photons have no charge.

persistent.gap: You're confusing photons with other particles.
persistent.action: Make a table: Photon (massless, chargeless, light) vs Electron (mass, charge, matter).

planck_constant_value.name: Planck's Constant Value
planck_constant_value.correct: Planck's constant h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s in SI units, or 4.14 × 10⁻¹⁵ eV·s when using electronvolts.

6.63 × 10⁻²⁷ J·s.error: Wrong exponent. Off by 7 orders of magnitude.
6.63 × 10⁻²⁷ J·s.action: Memorise: h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s. Check your data sheet.

1.06 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s.action: E = hf uses h, not ℏ. Know which constant you need.

6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ eV·s.error: Wrong units. That value goes with J·s, not eV·s.
6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ eV·s.action: Match: 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s OR 4.14 × 10⁻¹⁵ eV·s. Never mix.

persistent.gap: You're not reliably recalling Planck's constant.
persistent.action: Write h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s ten times. Then use it in three calculations.

photon_energy_formula.name: Photon Energy Formula
photon_energy_formula.correct: Photon energy E = hf, and since c = fλ, this also equals E = hc/λ. Both forms are equivalent.

E = hλ.error: Wrong operation. E is inversely proportional to λ, not directly.
E = hλ.fix: E = hc/λ. Wavelength is in the denominator. Longer λ = less energy.
E = hλ.action: Red light (long λ) has less energy than blue (short λ). E ∝ 1/λ.

E = h/f.error: Inverted. E is directly proportional to frequency.
E = h/f.fix: E = hf. Higher frequency = more energy. f is multiplied, not divided.
E = h/f.action: UV (high f) damages skin, radio waves (low f) don't. E = hf.

E = fλ.error: You've confused this with c = fλ for wave speed.
E = fλ.fix: c = fλ relates speed, frequency, and wavelength. E = hf relates energy and frequency.
E = fλ.action: Don't confuse wave equation (c = fλ) with energy equation (E = hf).

persistent.gap: You're not clear on the photon energy formula structure.
persistent.action: Write both forms: E = hf and E = hc/λ. Use each to calculate energy for a 500 nm photon.

frequency_energy_relationship.name: Frequency-Energy Relationship
frequency_energy_relationship.correct: Photon energy is directly proportional to frequency. Double the frequency, double the energy.

inversely proportional.error: Opposite. Higher frequency means MORE energy, not less.
inversely proportional.fix: E = hf shows direct proportion. More f = more E.
inversely proportional.action: X-rays (high f) are more dangerous than radio (low f). Why? More energy.

independent of frequency.error: They're directly linked by E = hf.
independent of frequency.action: Change f in E = hf. E changes too. They're not independent.

exponentially related.fix: E = hf is a straight line through the origin. Linear relationship.
exponentially related.action: Plot E vs f. You get a straight line with gradient h.

persistent.gap: You don't understand direct proportionality in E = hf.
persistent.action: Calculate E for f = 1, 2, 3 × 10¹⁴ Hz. See the linear pattern.

wavelength_energy_relationship.name: Wavelength-Energy Relationship
wavelength_energy_relationship.correct: Photon energy is inversely proportional to wavelength. Shorter wavelength means more energy.

directly proportional.fix: E = hc/λ. λ in denominator means inverse relationship.
directly proportional.action: UV has short λ and causes sunburn. IR has long λ and just warms you.

independent of wavelength.fix: Wavelength determines energy through the inverse relationship.
independent of wavelength.action: Blue light (short λ) has more energy than red (long λ).

equal to wavelength.fix: E = hc/λ, not E = λ. Different units, inverse relationship.
equal to wavelength.action: Check units: E is in joules, λ is in metres. Can't be equal.

persistent.gap: You're confusing direct and inverse proportionality.
persistent.action: Calculate E for λ = 400 nm and λ = 800 nm. Doubling λ halves E.

electronvolt_definition.name: Electronvolt Definition
electronvolt_definition.correct: An electronvolt is the energy gained by one electron accelerated through 1 volt. 1 eV = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ J.

1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ V.error: Wrong units. Electronvolt is energy (like joules), not voltage.
1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ V.fix: eV is a unit of ENERGY. 1 eV = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ J (joules).
1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ V.action: electron-volt = energy an electron gains from 1 volt. It's energy, not voltage.

6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J.error: That's Planck's constant, not the eV conversion.
6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J.fix: 1 eV = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ J. Don't confuse with h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s.
6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J.action: Different constants: eV conversion vs Planck's constant. Know both.

1.6 × 10⁻³⁴ J.action: Memorise: 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ is the electron charge AND the eV-to-J conversion.

persistent.gap: You're not reliably converting between eV and joules.
persistent.action: Practice: Convert 2 eV to J. Convert 3.2 × 10⁻¹⁹ J to eV.

speed_of_light_value.name: Speed of Light
speed_of_light_value.correct: The speed of light in vacuum c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s. All electromagnetic radiation travels at this speed.

3.0 × 10⁶ m/s.error: Wrong exponent. Off by 2 orders of magnitude.
3.0 × 10⁶ m/s.fix: c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s, not 10⁶. That's 300 million m/s.
3.0 × 10⁶ m/s.action: Light travels 300,000 km in one second. 10⁸, not 10⁶.

3.0 × 10⁸ km/s.error: Wrong units. It's m/s, not km/s.
3.0 × 10⁸ km/s.action: SI units use metres. c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s.

depends on frequency.error: In vacuum, all EM waves travel at the same speed.
depends on frequency.fix: c is constant in vacuum. All frequencies, same speed.
depends on frequency.action: Red and blue light both travel at c in vacuum.

persistent.gap: You're not reliably recalling the speed of light.
persistent.action: c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s. Use it in E = hc/λ calculations until automatic.

wavelength_frequency_conversion.name: Wavelength-Frequency Conversion
wavelength_frequency_conversion.correct: Since c = fλ, you can convert between wavelength and frequency using f = c/λ or λ = c/f.

f = cλ.error: Wrong operation. It's division, not multiplication.
f = cλ.fix: f = c/λ. Frequency equals speed divided by wavelength.
f = cλ.action: Check units: (m/s) / m = 1/s = Hz. Division works.

f = λ/c.error: Inverted. c divided by λ, not λ divided by c.
f = λ/c.fix: c = fλ rearranges to f = c/λ.
f = λ/c.action: Solve c = fλ for f algebraically. You get f = c/λ.

f = λc.error: Same as f = cλ. Wrong operation.
f = λc.fix: It's f = c/λ. Wavelength is in the denominator.
f = λc.action: Shorter wavelength = higher frequency. That requires division.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly rearranging c = fλ.
persistent.action: Practice: find f for λ = 500 nm, find λ for f = 6 × 10¹⁴ Hz.

em_spectrum_energy_order.name: EM Spectrum Energy Order
em_spectrum_energy_order.formula: Gamma > X-ray > UV > Visible > IR > Microwave > Radio
em_spectrum_energy_order.correct: Gamma rays have the highest photon energy (shortest λ, highest f). Radio waves have the lowest (longest λ, lowest f).

Radio > Microwave > IR > Visible > UV >.error: Completely reversed. That's wavelength order, not energy order.
Radio > Microwave > IR > Visible > UV >.fix: High frequency = high energy. Gamma highest, radio lowest.
Radio > Microwave > IR > Visible > UV >.action: Gamma rays damage cells. Radio waves don't. Energy matters.

all equal.fix: E = hf. Different f means different E.
all equal.action: X-rays penetrate tissue, visible light doesn't. Different energies.

depends on intensity.error: Intensity affects number of photons, not energy per photon.
depends on intensity.fix: Individual photon energy depends only on frequency.
depends on intensity.action: A dim X-ray photon still has more energy than a bright red photon.

persistent.gap: You're confusing photon energy with intensity or wavelength order.
persistent.action: Memorise: short λ = high f = high E. Gamma highest, radio lowest.

intensity_vs_energy.name: Intensity vs Photon Energy
intensity_vs_energy.formula: Intensity = number of photons; E = hf = energy per photon
intensity_vs_energy.correct: Intensity is the number of photons per second. Photon energy depends only on frequency, not intensity.

intensity determines photon energy.error: Wrong. Each photon's energy is set by its frequency only.
intensity determines photon energy.fix: Brighter light = more photons, not higher-energy photons.
intensity determines photon energy.action: A bright red laser has more photons than a dim one, but same energy per photon.

more intense light has higher frequency.fix: You can have intense low-frequency light or dim high-frequency light.
more intense light has higher frequency.action: A bright red lamp vs a dim UV lamp. Which photons have more energy?

photon energy increases with brightness.error: Brightness affects count, not individual photon energy.
photon energy increases with brightness.fix: Turn up a lamp: more photons per second, same energy each.
photon energy increases with brightness.action: Doubling lamp brightness doubles photon count, not photon energy.

persistent.gap: You're confusing intensity (photon count) with photon energy.
persistent.action: Separate them: Intensity = how many. Energy = how much per photon (from f).

unit_conversion_nm_to_m.name: Nanometre Conversion
unit_conversion_nm_to_m.correct: Wavelengths are often given in nanometres. 1 nm = 10⁻⁹ m = 0.000000001 m.

10⁻⁶ m.fix: nano = 10⁻⁹, micro = 10⁻⁶. nm is smaller than μm.

10⁻¹² m.fix: nano = 10⁻⁹, pico = 10⁻¹². nm is larger than pm.

10⁻³ m.fix: nano = 10⁻⁹, milli = 10⁻³. nm is much smaller.
10⁻³ m.action: Visible wavelengths are hundreds of nm, less than a micron.

persistent.gap: You're not reliably converting metric prefixes.

quantisation.title: Understanding Quantisation
quantisation.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of energy quantisation.

sentences.text: The term 'quantised' means that energy can only exist in {{d1}} amounts, rather than taking any arbitrary value. This concept was first introduced by Max {{d2}} to explain blackbody radiation.

d1.tooltip: Think: specific allowed values, like steps on a staircase

sentences.text: A photon is defined as a {{d3}} particle of electromagnetic radiation that carries a specific amount of {{d4}}. Unlike electrons, photons have {{d5}} mass.

d3.tooltip: What property do photons lack that electrons have?

d5.tooltip: Photons travel at the speed of light because they have no...

photon_formula.title: The Photon Energy Formula
photon_formula.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of E = hf = hc/λ.

sentences.text: The energy of a photon can be calculated using E = {{d1}}, where h is {{d2}} constant and f is the frequency of the light.

d1.tooltip: Energy is directly proportional to frequency

d2.tooltip: Which constant has units of J·s?

sentences.text: Since c = fλ, the photon energy formula can also be written as E = {{d3}}. In this form, photon energy is {{d4}} proportional to wavelength.

d3.tooltip: Wavelength is in the denominator because shorter λ means more energy

sentences.text: The value of Planck's constant in SI units is {{d5}} J·s. This extremely small value explains why quantum effects are not noticed in everyday life.

d5.tooltip: The exponent is 34, matching the number of letters in 'Planck' times 5 plus 4

calculations.title: Photon Energy Calculations
calculations.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of energy calculations.

sentences.text: When using E = hf with energy in joules, use h = {{d1}} J·s. When using energy in electronvolts, use h = {{d2}} eV·s.

d2.tooltip: This is h expressed in eV·s

sentences.text: The conversion between electronvolts and joules is 1 eV = {{d3}} J. This value equals the magnitude of the {{d4}} charge.

d3.tooltip: Same as the electron charge magnitude

d4.tooltip: electron-volt: energy gained by an electron through 1 volt

sentences.text: To convert wavelength to frequency, use f = c/λ where c = {{d5}} m/s. This relationship comes from the wave equation c = fλ.

applications.title: Applications of Photon Energy
applications.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of photon energy applications.

sentences.text: In the electromagnetic spectrum, {{d1}} rays have the highest photon energy because they have the {{d2}} frequency.

d1.tooltip: Which type is most dangerous to living cells?

d2.tooltip: E = hf: more frequency means more energy

sentences.text: Radio waves have {{d3}} photon energy than visible light because they have {{d4}} wavelengths.

d3.tooltip: Radio waves are at the low-energy end of the spectrum

d4.tooltip: E = hc/λ: longer wavelength means less energy

sentences.text: Increasing the intensity of a light source increases the {{d5}} of photons but does not change the {{d6}} of each individual photon.

d5.tooltip: Brighter means more photons per second

d6.tooltip: Each photon's energy is determined by frequency alone

quantisation.title: Applying Quantisation Concepts
quantisation.instructions: Apply your understanding of energy quantisation to these scenarios.

sentences.text: Einstein extended Planck's quantisation idea to explain the photoelectric effect, proposing that light itself comes in packets called {{d1}}. This particle model of light was controversial because it seemed to contradict the well-established {{d2}} model.

d1.tooltip: The particle name for a quantum of light

d2.tooltip: Young's double slit had established light as...

sentences.text: Unlike classical waves where energy can have any value, each photon carries exactly {{d3}} quantum of energy. The magnitude of this energy is determined entirely by the photon's {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Each photon = one packet of energy

d4.tooltip: E = hf shows energy depends on...

sentences.text: The quantisation of light energy explains why {{d5}} light cannot cause certain chemical reactions regardless of intensity, while {{d6}} light can trigger them even at low intensity.

d5.tooltip: Which visible colour has the lowest photon energy?

d6.tooltip: Which has enough energy to cause sunburn?

photon_formula.title: Working with the Energy Formula
photon_formula.instructions: Apply the photon energy formula to these scenarios.

sentences.text: The formula E = hc/λ shows that photon energy and wavelength have an {{d1}} relationship. Halving the wavelength will {{d2}} the photon energy.

d2.tooltip: If λ becomes half, what happens to hc/λ?

sentences.text: The gradient of a graph of photon energy versus frequency equals {{d3}}. This relationship is {{d4}} and passes through the origin.

d3.tooltip: E = hf is y = mx form, where m = ?

d4.tooltip: E = hf graphs as a straight line

sentences.text: For a photon with λ = 500 nm, you must first convert to metres: 500 nm = 500 × {{d5}} m = 5.0 × 10⁻⁷ m. The conversion factor from nm to m is {{d6}}.

calculations.title: Energy Calculation Practice
calculations.instructions: Apply the formulas to calculate photon energies.

sentences.text: A photon with frequency 6.0 × 10¹⁴ Hz has energy E = hf = (6.63 × 10⁻³⁴)(6.0 × 10¹⁴) = {{d1}} J. To convert this to eV, divide by {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Multiply the mantissas, add the exponents

sentences.text: Using E = hc/λ, a 400 nm photon has {{d3}} energy than a 700 nm photon because 400 nm is {{d4}} than 700 nm and energy varies inversely with wavelength.

d4.tooltip: 400 nm vs 700 nm: which is smaller?

sentences.text: When calculating photon energy in electronvolts directly, use h = 4.14 × 10⁻¹⁵ eV·s and the result will be in {{d5}}. The advantage is avoiding the {{d6}} conversion step.

d5.tooltip: Using h in eV·s gives energy in...

d6.tooltip: What conversion is avoided by using h in eV·s?

applications.title: Real-World Photon Energy Applications
applications.instructions: Apply photon energy concepts to practical situations.

sentences.text: X-rays can penetrate soft tissue because each X-ray photon has {{d1}} energy than visible light photons. This high energy comes from X-rays having much {{d2}} wavelengths.

d1.tooltip: X-rays are higher on the energy scale than visible light

d2.tooltip: E = hc/λ: more energy requires shorter λ

sentences.text: A laser pointer and the Sun both emit red light at 650 nm. Each {{d3}} photon has the same energy regardless of the source. The difference is the Sun emits far {{d4}} photons per second.

d3.tooltip: What determines photon energy? Wavelength, not source.

d4.tooltip: The Sun is brighter due to more photons, not higher-energy ones

sentences.text: Digital cameras detect individual photons. A photon from a {{d5}} LED will register with less energy than one from a {{d6}} LED, even if the blue LED appears dimmer.

d5.tooltip: Which colour has the longest wavelength in visible light?

d6.tooltip: Which visible colour has the highest photon energy?

quantisation.title: Mastering Quantisation Concepts
quantisation.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of energy quantisation.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that brighter light has higher-energy photons. In reality, brightness relates to photon {{d1}}, while individual photon energy depends only on {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: E = hf links energy to what property?

sentences.text: The quantisation of photon energy resolves the ultraviolet catastrophe from classical physics. Classical theory predicted {{d3}} energy at high frequencies, but quantisation limits each photon to energy E = {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Classical physics predicted impossibly large values at high f

sentences.text: Photons differ from matter particles in that they are {{d5}} and always travel at speed {{d6}} in vacuum. Despite having no mass, they carry both energy and momentum.

d6.tooltip: All electromagnetic waves travel at this speed in vacuum

photon_formula.title: Complete Formula Mastery
photon_formula.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of the photon energy formulas.

sentences.text: The two forms E = hf and E = hc/λ are equivalent because c = fλ. Substituting f = c/λ into E = hf gives E = h(c/λ) = {{d1}}. This shows that knowing either {{d2}} or wavelength is sufficient to find photon energy.

d2.tooltip: f and λ are related by c = fλ

sentences.text: A graph of E versus 1/λ would be a straight line with gradient {{d3}}. This is because E = hc × (1/λ), which has the form y = mx where m = {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: The coefficient of (1/λ) in E = hc/λ

sentences.text: When Planck's constant h is expressed in eV·s as 4.14 × 10⁻¹⁵, the product hc equals approximately {{d5}} eV·nm. This allows direct calculation from wavelength in nm to energy in {{d6}}.

d6.tooltip: Using h in eV·s gives energy in...

sentences.text: A 100 W light bulb emitting only 555 nm green light would emit approximately {{d1}} photons per second, found by dividing total power by energy per photon. Power equals {{d2}} times photon energy.
To find the wavelength of a 2.5 eV photon, rearrange E = hc/λ to λ = hc/E = (1240 eV·nm)/(2.5 eV) = {{d3}} nm. This is in the {{d4}} region of the spectrum.
Doubling the frequency of light {{d5}} its photon energy and {{d6}} its wavelength. These relationships follow directly from E = hf and c = fλ.

d5.tooltip: E = hf: if f doubles, E...?

d6.tooltip: c = fλ: if f doubles and c is constant, λ...?

applications.title: Synthesis and Problem Solving
applications.instructions: Synthesise your knowledge to solve complex problems.

sentences.text: In photosynthesis, chlorophyll absorbs {{d1}} and blue light efficiently but reflects green light. This is because red and blue photons have energies that {{d2}} the energy gaps in chlorophyll molecules.

d1.tooltip: Plants absorb the colours that aren't reflected

d2.tooltip: Energy transitions require specific photon energies

sentences.text: Night vision devices amplify {{d3}} photons which have lower energy than visible light. These photons have longer wavelengths and therefore {{d4}} frequencies than red light.

d4.tooltip: c = fλ: longer λ means lower f

sentences.text: The photoelectric effect requires photons above a threshold {{d5}} because each electron needs a minimum energy to escape the metal. Increasing light {{d6}} cannot compensate for insufficient photon energy.

d5.tooltip: Below threshold frequency, no electrons are emitted

d6.tooltip: More photons doesn't help if each photon has insufficient energy
